column1: BOIL WATER ORDER ISSUED FOR LOS TULES MUTUAL WATER COMPANY IN WARNER SPRINGS
<article class=""node node-page node-promoted article odd node-full clearfix"" id=""article-13773"" role=""article"">
Printer-friendly version

• August 2013 Articles
  • Warner Springs
  • Los Tules Mutual Water company
  • boil water order
  • E. Coli

August 14, 2013 (San Diego’s East County) – The County of San Diego, Department of Environmental Health (DEH) has issued a Boil Water Order and Public Notification for the Los Tules Mutual Water Company located at 32995 Camino Moro, Warner Springs, CA 92086 effective immediately.  This public water system serves 100 residential homes.

The drinking water system has tested present for total coliform bacteria and absent for E. coli.  Total coliform bacteria can come from soils and other sources in the environment and can indicate a problem with the water supply system.  The Boil Water Order was issued to ensure all water used is free from contamination.  The Boil Water Order will remain in effect until the distribution system has been disinfected and additional samples confirm the absence of bacteria in the water supply.

Boil water notice issued for parts of Slidell
<time aria-label=""Article Published Date and Time"" class=""dateline__published"" datetime=""2013-08-15T12:32"" id=""dateline__published"">Posted on August 15, 2013 at 12:32 PM</time>
By Heather Nolan, NOLA.com
hnolan@nola.com

The city of Slidell and the State Department of Health and Hospitals have issued a boil water advisory for parts of the city around Northshore Boulevard. This includes areas north and south of Interstate 12 and Camp Villere, according to a news release from the city.

The advisory is being issued because of a drop in water pressure caused by a driver who hit a fire hydrant. That caused an uncontrolled flow of water, according to the city.

Those affected by the advisory should boil tap water before drinking, bathing or rinsing food with it. Keep water at a rolling boil for at least a minute before using it until the advisory is lifted.

The pumping system is operating fully again, but the city said it is following strict Department of Health and Hospitals standards and testing water samples to confirm that it is safe to consume.

column10: w=300 300w""/>(from the City of Slidell) – The City of Slidell, in consultation with the State Department of Health and Hospitals (DHH), has issued a boil water advisory on Thursday morning for limited sections of Slidell around Northshore Boulevard. The area includes commercial areas north and south of Interstate 12, as well as Camp Villere. This advisory follows a drop in pressure caused by a driver who hit a fire hydrant causing an uncontrolled flow of water.

column1: Businesses and other affected interests are asked boil tap water before drinking, bathing or rinsing food with it. The protocol is to keep water at a rolling boil for at least a minute before using it until the advisory is lifted.
Although the pumping system is operating fully again, the City of Slidell is following strict DHH standards and testing water samples to confirm that it is safe to consume.
